docs.lead_paragraph: The chief executive of one of California's largest health insurers is calling for legislation that would provide public or private health coverage for every resident of California. Bruce G. Bodaken, the chief executive of Blue Shield of California, a nonprofit insurer with 2.6 million members, said his plan would require most employers in the state to provide essential health benefits for every employee as part of a proposal to cover six million uninsured state residents.

headline.main: A Call for Universal Health Care in California

docs.abstract: Blue Shield of California chief executive Bruce G Bodaken calls for legislation that would provide public or private health coverage for every California resident; state has six million uninsured (M)
docs.snippet: The chief executive of one of California's largest health insurers is calling for legislation that would provide public or private health coverage for every resident of California.     Bruce G. Bodaken, the chief executive of Blue Shield of...

docs.lead_paragraph: Carping critics of the conservative movement have been known to say that its economic program consists of little more than tax cuts, tax cuts and more tax cuts. I may even have said that myself. If so, I apologize. Emboldened by the midterm election, key conservative ideologues have now declared their support for tax increases -- but only for people with low incomes. The public debut of this idea came, as such things often do, on the editorial page of The Wall Street Journal. The page's editors, it seems, are upset that some low-income people pay little or nothing in income taxes. Not, mind you, because of the lost revenue, but because these ''lucky duckies'' -- The Journal's term, not mine -- might not be feeling a proper hatred for the government.
docs.abstract: Paul Krugman Op-Ed column claims today's conservative movement is relentless and extremist; says recent Wall Street Journal editorial, calling for taxes on poorest Americans and tax cuts for wealthiest, reveals political theory that government policy should be 'nasty' to people with low incomes, lest they have any good feelings about government; says 'compassionate conservatism' and 'leave no child behind' are empty slogans; hopes moderate Republicans will realize what has happened to their party; says eventually public, which benefits from programs political right is determined to abolish, will figure that out (M)
docs.snippet: Carping critics of the conservative movement have been known to say that its economic program consists of little more than tax cuts, tax cuts and more tax cuts. I may even have said that myself. If so, I apologize. Emboldened by the midterm election,...

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: President Bush signed legislation limiting insurers' liability by putting American taxpayers on the hook for property damage caused by terrorism (front page, Nov. 27). Insurers claimed that they could not shoulder the risk of providing ''terrorism insurance'' without government assistance. Shouldn't building owners and insurers bear the risks of their chosen businesses without begging for a handout from the government? What about self-reliance and the free market?
docs.abstract: Terence D Edwards letter scores legislation signed by Pres Bush that limits insurers' liability by putting American taxpayers on hook for property damage caused by terrorism (Nov 27 article); holds such corporate welfare is particularly galling given that 40 million hard-working Americans still lack basic health insurance

docs.lead_paragraph: * Burger King Corp., Miami, part of Diageo, expanded its relationship with Draft Worldwide, Chicago, by naming the agency's Premium Surge unit to help handle promotions of children's toys, sharing duties with Equity Marketing, Los Angeles. Spending has not been determined. Draft, part of the Partnership division of the Interpublic Group of Companies, is agency of record for Burger King promotions. * PacifiCare Health Systems, Cypress, Calif., to Anita Santiago Advertising, Santa Monica, Calif., to create campaigns for a new health insurance program, Latino Health Solutions. Spending was estimated at $1.5 million.

docs.lead_paragraph: We sit around a large table in the conference room of the First Choice Community Health Center here. A purple paisley sheet, hung with duct tape, covers the window fronting the parking lot. In a corner is a wheeled cart stacked with hospital gowns, gauze pads, syringes and a hydroculator unit, a metal tank containing hot packs in a water bath. There are nine of us, including Magda P., who sits at the head of the table, and all of us are munching grapes and Hershey Kisses from the communal snacks on the table.

headline.main: In Pain Clinic, Fruit, Candy And Relief

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Drastic Surgery for Drastic Obesity'' (editorial, Nov. 24): For many suffering with morbid obesity, access to weight loss surgery is all too often denied by insurance carriers, including Medicare. These carriers either do not recognize morbid obesity as a disease or they place so many arbitrary obstacles in the path of patients that approval becomes impossible. A legislative remedy is sorely needed.

headline.main: Get the Weight Off: Healthy Ideas

docs.abstract: Letter from Dr Louis Flancbaum says more research funds are needed to study morbid obesity and effects of surgical treatment described in Nov 24 editorial

docs.lead_paragraph: Qadri Skipper leapt off the bus, holding the straps of his backpack in midair like a paratrooper. Another day of third grade behind him, he barreled through the front door of his home and into his mother's arms, where short kisses and long hugs were exchanged. Next stop: the refrigerator. Qadri poured himself a tall glass of strawberry milk, then sat down at a small table off the living room to tackle some homework.

headline.main: The Neediest Cases; Sick Boys' Families Share Love, Hope and Overwhelming Bills

docs.lead_paragraph: IN the weeks since Governor McGreevey unveiled an ambitious plan to reorganize the state's university system, alternating currents of hope and fear have been pulsing through faculty members and administrators who could be affected by such a vast change. The goal of the governor, simple enough in its complexity, is the consolidation of the state's universities -- Rutgers, the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey, which has eight health education-related schools, and the New Jersey Institute of Technology -- with an emphasis on improving medical education and building a national reputation for research.

headline.main: At Medical Schools, A Time of Change

docs.abstract: Article on proposal by Gov James McGreevey to consolidate Rutgers, University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey and New Jersey Institute of Technology; faculty members and administrators, contrary to assertion that primary goals are to improve medical education and garner national reputation for research, fear restructuring would cut jobs and threaten job security; photos (L)
